examples: The chef added a conservative amount of salt to the dish.

definitions.definition: Tending to resist change or innovation .
examples: The curriculum committee at this university is extremely conservative .

definitions.definition: Based on pessimistic assumptions , and on the low side.
examples: At a conservative estimate, growth may even be negative next year.

definitions.definition: Supporting some combination of fiscal , political or social conservatism .
definitions.label_groups: US , Canada , economics , politics , social sciences

definitions.definition: Neither creating nor destroying a given quantity.
Having power to preserve in a safe or entire state, or from loss, waste, or injury; preservative .
Conventional, traditional, and moderate in style and appearance; not extreme, excessive, faddish, or intense.
Not including any operation or intervention (said of a treatment, see conservative treatment )
Having few changes relative to an older form, especially in comparison to related varieties.
examples: While innovative in its verbal system, Sardinian is the most conservative Romance language in its vocabulary and phonology.

definitions.definition: That is the gradient of a function .

secondary_definitions: Tending to resist change or innovation .
Based on pessimistic assumptions , and on the low side.
( US , Canada , economics , politics , social sciences ) Supporting some combination of fiscal , political or social conservatism .
( British , politics ) Relating to the Conservative Party .
( physics , not comparable ) Neither creating nor destroying a given quantity.
Having power to preserve in a safe or entire state, or from loss, waste, or injury; preservative .
( clothing ) Conventional, traditional, and moderate in style and appearance; not extreme, excessive, faddish, or intense.
( medicine ) Not including any operation or intervention (said of a treatment, see conservative treatment )
( linguistics ) Having few changes relative to an older form, especially in comparison to related varieties.
( calculus , of field ) That is the gradient of a function .
